--- title: "Taxonomy of Data" format: revealjs: author: "STAT 20: Introduction to Probability and Statistics" height: 900 width: 1600 theme: ../../assets/slides.scss multiplex: false transition: fade slide-number: c incremental: false center: false menu: false highlight-style: github progress: false code-overflow: wrap title-slide-attributes: data-background-image: ../../assets/stat20-hex-bg.png data-background-size: contain --- ::: notes 1. Review discussion of reading and address common questions 2. Concept questions - easy one - hard one (shoebill) 3. Practice handout break 4. Lab - instructor demo then walk around and troubleshoot ::: ## Agenda - Concept Questions: Taxonomy of Data - Reading Questions - Practice Problems - *Break* - Lab 1: Getting Started # Concept Questions ## *Variable*: A characteristic that varies from individual to individual. Examples: - Height - Weight - Glucose level - Eye color - Handedness - Zip code \ \ ## ::: poll What type of variable is *age*? ::: ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
01:00
``` ::: ::: ## {data-menu-title="Shoebill Pic 1" background-image="images/shoebill-1.png" background-size="contain"} ## Images as data ::: columns ::: {.column .incremental width="55%"} - Images are composed of pixels (this image is 1012 by 1520) - The color in each pixel is in RGB ![](images/rgb.png){width="460"} - Each band takes a value from 0-255 - This image is data with 1020 x 1520 x 3 values. ::: ::: {.column width="45%"} ![](images/shoebill-1.png){fig-alt="A shoebill with a duck in its mouth." width="800"} ::: ::: ## Grayscale ::: columns ::: {.column .incremental width="55%"} - Grayscale images have only one band - 0 is black, 255 is white - This image is data with 1020 x 1520 x 1 values. ::: fragment > To simplify, assume our photos are 8 x 8 grayscale images. ::: ::: ::: {.column width="45%"} ![](images/shoebill-1-grayscale.png){fig-alt="A shoebill with a duck in its mouth in grayscale." width="800"} ::: ::: ## Images in a Data Frame ::: columns ::: {.column width="33%"} ![](images/shoebill-1.png) ::: ::: {.column width="33%"} ![](images/shoebill-2.png) ::: ::: {.column width="34%"} ![](images/shoebill-3.png) ::: ::: ::: poll If you were to put the data from these (8 x 8 grayscale) images into a data frame, what would the dimensions of that data frame be in rows x columns? ::: ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
04:00
``` ::: ::: ::: notes 8x8 gray scale dimensions 3 rows for each image, 64 columns with numbers from 0-255. But walk through some of the student answers and ask students to explain ::: # Reading Questions ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
05:00
``` ::: ::: ## The following questions are based on the data frame shown below: ![](images/reading-question-1.png) ## Question 1.1 Not counting the course numbers, how many variables are recorded in this data frame? The choices went from 0 to 7. ## Question 1.2 What type of variable is the number of students? ( ) Integer ( ) Continuous Numerical ( ) Discrete Numerical ( ) Logical ( ) Ordinal Categorical ( ) Nominal Categorical ## Question 1.3 What is the *most specific* term that can be given to this data structure? ( ) Spreadsheet ( ) Table ( ) Contingency Table ( ) Data Frame ( ) Data Table # Question 2 What is the statistics term used for a property of an object that can be measured and recorded? ( ) Data ( ) Variable ( ) Constant ( ) Observational Unit ( ) Numerical # Worksheet 1 ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
20:00
``` ::: ::: # Worksheet 2: Getting Started with Markdown ## Steps: - Go to the course website, and download qmd file. Save it on your computer. Log into *stat20.datahub.berkeley.edu*. You can go there from our course site. - log in using your Calnet credentials - This is RStudio in the cloud!! - Upload your file. - Enjoy

include-after-body:
<script>
  // htmlwidgets need to know to resize themselves when slides are shown/hidden.
  // Fire the "slideenter" event (handled by htmlwidgets.js) when the current
  // slide changes (different for each slide format).
  (function () {
    // dispatch for htmlwidgets
    function fireSlideEnter() {
      const event = window.document.createEvent("Event");
      event.initEvent("slideenter", true, true);
      window.document.dispatchEvent(event);
    }

    function fireSlideChanged(previousSlide, currentSlide) {
      fireSlideEnter();

      // dispatch for shiny
      if (window.jQuery) {
        if (previousSlide) {
          window.jQuery(previousSlide).trigger("hidden");
        }
        if (currentSlide) {
          window.jQuery(currentSlide).trigger("shown");
        }
      }
    }

    // hookup for slidy
    if (window.w3c_slidy) {
      window.w3c_slidy.add_observer(function (slide_num) {
        // slide_num starts at position 1
        fireSlideChanged(null, w3c_slidy.slides[slide_num - 1]);
      });
    }

  })();
</script>
